15 Alfred Workflows to Turbocharge Productivity

May 2, 2014
5 minute read

Back in the day, I was obsessed with Launchy, a small utility that acted as an application launcher/script runner/multi-purpose tool on Windows. It felt so cool to have a quick assistant that responded intelligently to my commands.

When I first moved to OS X in 2007, I found my replacement for Launchy: OS X’s built-in Spotlight. It seemed to do the trick: I could launch apps, find files, do math…fine and dandy. Over time (and by that, I mean 6 years of time), I fell out of love with Spotlight. It just didn’t have the pizzaz I was looking for.

At some point in that 6 year stretch, I stumbled across Quicksilver, a Launchy equivalent on OS X. To be truthful, I didn’t like it. It seemed clunky, like something that had been popular in a bygone era, but was now showing its age (much like Launchy itself). Nope.

And then I found Alfred 2. And much like Alfred Pennyworth1, I loved him. Allow me to share why I love him so much.

TL;DR

I’ve finally started to get into Alfred 2; I’m also wondering how I lived without it for so long.

The Setup

By itself, Alfred is very powerful. However, its true power is hidden it its Powerpack, a great set of tools and extensions that are absolutely worth the $30 price tag. Most crucial for me among the Powerpack’s features are workflows:

Create immensely powerful workflows by connecting keywords, hotkeys and actions together to extend Alfred to do amazing things without writing a single line of code!

If that doesn’t sound like a productivity nerd’s best friend, I don’t know what does.

Workflows

Here are the 15 workflows that boost my productivity and make a better citizen of humanity.

Alfred for Trello

I’ve mentioned my love for Trello. This workflow allows me to quickly add cards to my “INBOX” board: when I want to jot an idea into Trello, this gets the job done.

 Colors

My job constantly demands that I translate between color formats (RGB, Hex, etc.). This workflow allows me to quickly figure these values out and send them to other apps, workflows, etc.

Doit.im

Doit.im has become new favorite task manager. Its OS X app allows for quick entry of tasks, but when I’m immersed in Alfred-ness2, it’s often easier to just add the task here.

Encode/Decode

Like color translation, my job also features a lot of URL and HTML encoding. To date, I’ve used Eric Meyer’s timeless URL Decoder/Encoder, but I realize now that’s too many steps. This workflow gives me the power I need.

Evernote

(look at that enormous list of actions!)

You know what else takes too many steps? Switching to Evernote and doing something.3 This workflow allows me to create/update notes, search for notes, and reminders, and much more.

Fantastical

I already use Fantastical on iOS and Fantastical on OS X; its natural language  parsing abilities are awesome. This workflow allows me to hook into the OS X app and easily add events.

GitHub

Despite the bad stuff that’s come out of it lately, I still rely heavily on GitHub for all my projects. This workflow allows me to search for repos, work with them, and so much more.

IP Address

How often have you wanted to look up your IP address (local or external)? ‘Nuff said.

Kill Process

When a process hangs, it’s a hassle to open Activity Monitor, search for it, and kill it. Once again, Alfred makes a repetitive task much faster.

Open With Atom

I recently started playing with Atom as my full-time editor; this workflow is a bit simple, but it allows me to quickly open files and begin editing.

Shorten URL

Shortening URLs (for tweets, emails, etc.) is a pain; you have to go to the website you want, enter your URL, wait for the transformation to occur, copy it, and move on. This allows for a quicker process across all the famous URL shorteners.

StackOverflow

I look at StackOverflow constantly; this workflow means I don’t have to manually open a browser, go there, and search the question.

TomatoTomato

I probably shouldn’t, but I rely on Rotten Tomatoes to tell me whether a movie is worth my time. This quick workflow allows me to see the scores quickly.

(And I can confirm: The Winter Soldier is worth seeing.)

Weather

My wife asks me at least once a day what the weather will be like tomorrow. Alfred to the rescue.

Workflow Searcher

Since all my other workflows eschew the need to open a browser, why wouldn’t I have a workflow to search for workflows?4

Other Cool Tidbits

Alfred can do so much more; here are some other nifty tricks for your consideration.

Clipboard History

I used to use ClipMenu for clipboard management on my Mac; although it did a swell job, I decided to remove it in favor of Alfred’s (which works equally well and saves me an extra app).

Locking Your Mac

Being in an office environment, I like to exercise caution by locking my Mac when I walk away. Surprisingly, OS X makes this really difficult to do in a quick way; Alfred solves that problem with the lock command.

Copying Contact Details

It might seem like a simple thing, but Alfred has some great contact management abilities. My favorite: quickly copy a contact’s email address, phone number, or other attributes with a keystroke.

What Else?

The possibilities with Alfred are limitless. What have you come up with to make your life more productive?

  2. Alfred-ness is the state of having Alfred rule your life. ↩
  3. Okay, that’s a bit dramatic, but seriously: this is an amazing time-saver. ↩
  4. This sounds dangerously like an infinite loop waiting to happen. ↩
